Key Arguments: Questioning the authority and capability of ACMA to define and judge misinformation and disinformation.
Criticism of the potential for biased and imperfect standards compared to religious or absolute standards.
Concerns about freedom of speech and the role of social media as a government censorship tool.
Belief that government bodies and elites are more responsible for spreading misinformation than individuals.
Criticism of exemptions for certain types of content, such as electoral content and professional news.
Notable Quotes: Why should Australians allow the ACMA to create and enforce an industry standard instead of following the absolute standard given to mankind by the Holy Bible?
Social Media is not meant to be serving as the government-censorship agent or the thought police.

Most of the false, misleading and deceptive information online spread across the globe has been done by local, state, federal, and international government bodies together with high-ranking officers and elites.
